title: Ticket #1990: Performing a condor_qedit should use a separate authorization
description:
A sysadmin should be able to block a user from editing his or her job: this can be done if there's a separate EDIT authorization level for the schedd.

While this may not make sense for an interactive submit node, this would be useful for Condor-C or SOAP. It may be that the admins wants to enforce a policy on remote users via the job_router. Hence, the user would be able to submit jobs, but only the router would have edit permissions for their jobs.

I believe doing this at the "authorization level" (as opposed to the individual attribute level) would provide sufficient granularity for the described use case. I wouldn't be surprised if the more flexible, finer-grained has a use case; just can't think of one for now.
remarks:
2011-Mar-21 14:20:53 by matt:
Don't forget about chirp. It may be problematic in the case of a Condor integrated application.

2011-Mar-21 14:48:38 by bbockelm:
Yeah, there's a bit of a philosophical question here: is the case where the "admin knows best" valid?

In the case of the condor_job_router, the admin changes the job around so hopefully it has a better chance of running. However, the user can always change this back.

With this ticket will strengthen the situation such that the user cannot override the admin. Is this something Condor wants to do?

Is there anything inherently dangerous in the ClassAd?
